Euler Number eee and its properties

What is eee?

eee is a special constant, approximately

e≈2.718281828…e \approx 2.718281828\ldots e≈2.718281828…

It is defined in several equivalent ways. At this point, we will use the limit definition:

Limit definition (compound interest):

e=lim⁡n→∞(1+1n)n.e = \lim_{n \to \infty}\Bigl(1 + \tfrac1n\Bigr)^n. e=n→∞lim​(1+n1​)n.

Natural logarithm

The natural logarithm, ln⁡(x)\ln(x)ln(x), is the inverse of the exponential function exe^xex.

ln⁡(x)=log⁡e(x)\ln(x) = \log_e(x) ln(x)=loge​(x)

The rest of this set of notes are for your reference and might make more sense later.

Additional properties of e

Properties of eee

  1. Irrationality: eee cannot be expressed as a fraction of two integers.
  2. Transcendence: eee is not a root of any nonzero polynomial with integer coefficients.
  3. Limit of a sequence:

    e=lim⁡n→∞(1+1n)n.e = \lim_{n \to \infty}\Bigl(1 + \tfrac1n\Bigr)^n. e=n→∞lim​(1+n1​)n.

  4. Infinite series expansion:

    e=∑k=0∞1k!.e = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{k!}. e=k=0∑∞​k!1​.

  5. Unique growth rate: among all exponential functions axa^xax, the function exe^xex is the only one whose rate of change at x=0x=0x=0 is exactly 1.
  6. Derivative and integral:

    ddxex=ex,∫ex dx=ex+C.\frac{d}{dx}e^x = e^x, \qquad \int e^x\,dx = e^x + C. dxd​ex=ex,∫exdx=ex+C.

  7. Euler’s formula (complex extension):

    eiθ=cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ,e^{i\theta} = \cos\theta + i\sin\theta, eiθ=cosθ+isinθ,

    which for θ=π\theta = \piθ=π gives the celebrated identity

    eiπ+1=0.e^{i\pi} + 1 = 0. eiπ+1=0.

Why do we care about eee?

  • Calculus: exe^xex is its own derivative and integral, making it central in solving differential equations.
  • Growth and decay models: continuous compound interest, population growth, radioactive decay all use eee.
  • Probability & statistics: appears in the Poisson distribution and normal distribution’s density function.
  • Complex analysis: Euler’s formula links exponential and trigonometric functions, underpinning Fourier analysis.
  • Natural logarithm: ln⁡(x)\ln(x)ln(x)—the inverse of exe^xex—simplifies many integrals and solves equations involving products and powers.

Alternative definitions

  1. Series definition:

    e=∑k=0∞1k!=1+1+12+16+124+⋯ .e = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{k!} = 1 + 1 + \tfrac12 + \tfrac1{6} + \tfrac1{24} + \cdots. e=k=0∑∞​k!1​=1+1+21​+61​+241​+⋯.

  2. Differential equation definition: the unique base for which the function f(x)=exf(x)=e^xf(x)=ex satisfies

    ddxex=exande0=1.\frac{d}{dx}e^x = e^x \quad\text{and}\quad e^0 = 1. dxd​ex=exande0=1.

  3. Via the natural logarithm:

    ln⁡(e)=1,andln⁡(x)=∫1x1t dt.\ln(e) = 1,\quad\text{and}\quad \ln(x) = \int_1^x \frac{1}{t}\,dt. ln(e)=1,andln(x)=∫1x​t1​dt.

  4. As the unique real number satisfying

    ∫1e1t dt=1.\int_1^e \frac{1}{t}\,dt = 1. ∫1e​t1​dt=1.

Applications and examples

  1. Continuous compounding:
    If an account pays interest at annual rate rrr compounded continuously, the balance after ttt years is

    A(t)=A0 ert.A(t) = A_0\,e^{rt}. A(t)=A0​ert.

  2. Differential equations:
    The solution to

    dydx=ky,y(0)=y0\frac{dy}{dx} = ky,\quad y(0)=y_0 dxdy​=ky,y(0)=y0​

    is

    y(x)=y0 ekx.y(x) = y_0\,e^{kx}. y(x)=y0​ekx.

  3. Approximating eee:
    Using the series up to k=5k=5k=5,

    e≈1+1+12+16+124+1120=2.716666…e \approx 1 + 1 + \tfrac12 + \tfrac16 + \tfrac1{24} + \tfrac1{120} = 2.716666\ldots e≈1+1+21​+61​+241​+1201​=2.716666…

  4. Compound interest example:
    $1000 at 5% interest for 3 years, continuously compounded:

    A=1000 e0.05×3≈1000×e0.15≈1000×1.1618=$1161.83.A = 1000\,e^{0.05 \times 3} \approx 1000 \times e^{0.15} \approx 1000 \times 1.1618 = \$1161.83. A=1000e0.05×3≈1000×e0.15≈1000×1.1618=$1161.83.
